intro: Acaena sericascens var. sexjuga, commonly known as the silver burr or silver cushion, is a low-growing, mat-forming shrub native to New Zealand. It features dense, silver-gray foliage that is covered in fine, silky hairs, giving it a distinctive appearance. The plant produces small, spiny fruits that contain seeds, which are dispersed by animals. It thrives in coastal and subalpine environments, often growing in well-drained soils. Due to its hardy nature, it is sometimes used in erosion control and as an ornamental plant.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena sericascens var. sexjuga is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the South Island, particularly in the Canterbury and Otago regions. This plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as grasslands and rocky areas. It is adapted to the temperate climate and well-drained soils of these regions. The variety is known for its distinctive bracts and is part of the native flora of New Zealand's ecological systems.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena sericascens var. sexjuga was mainly introduced to New Zealand.
